Name: Opus
Description: Opus is the third of the larger box games published by Pseudon. It is a musical game where players must match cards showing styles of music in the right combinations to score points. The board is quite nice-looking with spaces for cards on the top and musical staffs below that identify the combinations to be made.

Name: Erfenis
Description: Old Lord Humbug is rich. More than 600 years of thriftiness and savings in the family has left the Lord with considerable property, stocks, many family heirlooms and 100 million English pounds that will be distributed to the family members when the Lord dies. However, all of the heirs have already waited a very long time: the old Lord refuses  to die! He is already 86 and could live another 100 years! The possible heirs are: the sparing sister Lady Scrape Humbug, the poor old friend of the family Sir Humpty, Trickenham the butler, Miss Fuzzy the careless daughter, Spoiler Humbug the prodigal son,  and Vanity the ambitious mistress. They each try in every way possible to influence the old man, in an effort to win the him over and get the inheritance for themselves. Players in this game take the part of these heirs are.

Name: Track-Gammon
Description: Track-Gammon is a backgammon-like game. Each player has five pieces of different sizes;  the pieces must move out of the start in increasing order of size, but must enter the goal space in decreasing order of size.

Name: Subsidie
Description: Subsidie is a quick card game for 3 to 6 players and the players try to win projects with government grants. In addition several obstacles must be overcome: grants can be lost, somebody else can take over the project, the project can fail due to scandal... The purpose of the play is to apply enough government funds as possible for the realization of projects. The winner is who at the end of the play has applied the largest amount subsidy for realized projects.

Name: ConXion
Description: ConXion is an abstract game using hexagonal tiles. The game is primarily for three players (it can also be played by two or six). The object is to connect the opposing sides of the board in your color with the center. Tiles must be placed so they connect to the center. Instead of placing one of their tiles, a player can rotate anyone's tile, which can change the connectivity considerably.

Name: Käpt'n Jan
Description: Captain John is always busy sailing his ship transporting goods from far and wide. This is no easy task, because sometimes the parcels are long and thin, sometimes they have lots of corners or they are simply round. Now and then a great wave splashes onto the ship and sweeps a chest overboard. However, it is sometimes possible for the captain to fish the chest back on board again. If he maneuvers his ship well, the captain will manage to get all the goods to their destination safe and sound.

Name: Toccato
Description: Toccato is a 3-D abstract game that uses 12 poly-forms that can be made into a cube. Players must place and remove the stones to score in specific patterns.

Name: Felsberger Arena
Description: Felsberger Arena is a fast-action dexterity game played on a hexagonal board. Players flick marbles into the center felted play area to score points and knock opponents' marbles out. Made to the same high quality standards as the rest of the Felsberger lineup.

Name: Riegel
Description:
Riegel, which was designed by Paul Schobesberger (Austria), is an abstract game played on wooden board with 10 rows of sliders. Each row has depressions to hold marbles. Each player is trying to get their set of marbles from one side of the board to the other, but can only move onto certain depressions and thus the sliders must be positioned properly for movement. Made by Felsberger in the same high quality as their other games.

It is not an abstract strategy game since the moves are decided by dice according to http://toy-net.ch/felsberger/spielregeln/riegel.htm .

Name: Felsberger Nuggets
Description: Felsberger Nuggets in an abstract game made in the same high quality wooden format as the rest of the Felsberger lineup. The game uses four colored turntables each housing up to four marbles, and players must rotate the turntables to make color matches to remove the marbles.

Name: Labyrinth
Description: The Felsberger Labyrinth is a beautifully made game that plays very well. The high-quality board houses a set of movable channels and, as expected, the goal is to get the ball to flow the way you want it to. The board sits on a stand that allows it to tilt in any direction.

Name: Hamertjesspel
Description:
Hamertjesspel (Dutch for "The Little Mallet Game") is a traditional pub-game that was popular in the Low Lands of Belgium and the Netherlands and can be traced back as far as 1750. It could be regarded as an early form of Pinball, but despite its erstwhile popularity, it was all but forgotten in the latter half of the 20th century. Recently replica boards are making a bit of a comeback, and "het Hamertjesspel" can be seen again at village fêtes and other occasions that encourage nostalgic throw-back entertainment.

Four players sit on each side of a square wooden board with raised edges, defending their goal. A marble or small lead ball is dropped in the centre, either by hand or, on the more evolved board versions, through a "fair" central dropping device. Players try to get the marble into an opponent's goal, and keep their own one safe, by using a small wooden mallet ("Hamer" is Dutch for "Hammer"). To make life difficult for the players, the goal is split up in two by a centre isle, and spanned by a rail, so that it is impossible to block both halves simultaneously, or swap the hammer between goal sides easily. The board itself has a few obstacles (usually exposed nails) that deflect the marble.  Game play is best typified as frantic fun.

The boards tend to have a slight slope towards the centre point. The square versions commonly use 4 wood sections in a pyramid style. The "Karrewiel" (Cart Wheel), which is the round board version usually had more panes to create a nicer circular slope. Occasionally it would also be able to accommodate more than the standard 4 players, or have each player's goal area split in three gaps, rather than two. Most boards would have only one marble in play, but, reportedly, there are variants that had multiple balls simultaneously in the battle arena. If less people were playing, parts of the board could be blocked off using temporary wooden walls.

Traditionally, the first player to lose a certain amount of goals would have to buy the next round. Like all pub games, it was also played for money, and onlookers placed bets on the game's outcome.

In 1995 Battle Dome appeared, which is a modern flipper version of this traditional game, with a few added bells and whistles. In 2000 Felsburger produced the traditional Karrewiel version under the name Chüngel. Needless to say, most versions of the game keep coming from the Low Lands wood crafts cottage industry, that is slowly "rediscovering" this lost gem. And since the dimensions have never been standardised, quality and appearance are as diverse as the woodworkers making them.

Name: Challenge Sudoku
Description: 50 different Sudoku challenges. Three different ways to play: Standard, Challenge and Solitaire Sudoku.

Name: Hab acht!
Description:
Hab Acht ("Pay Attention") is a interesting memory variant, because it's motifs are printed on both sides of the tiles! There are 9 motifs printed on 36 tiles. Each front has a different backside, which means that every possible front/back-side is included in this game. Each motif is also printed on 9 task-tiles and every player draws 1 task-tile before the game begins.

Object of the game is to reveal all 8 motifs which match the task-tile. This can be quite difficult, especially, when you not also try to find "your" 8 motifs, but when you simultaneously try to inhibit certain motifs to come up, which apparently are being sought after from some of your opponents...

Name: Glückstreffer
Description: Glückstreffer ("Lucky Strike") is a Yahtzee variant, which makes use not only of usual dice numbers, but also of the colors they show. Every dice is printed with 1 red, blue, yellow and green side plus 2 sides in black. Accordingly, there are 6 dice used instead of the normal 5, so that it's possible to throw a row from 1-6 in every color.

Name: Weltkonferenz
Description:
The wife of the French President is found dead in her room. Who killed her?

All players (6 male, 3 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

Name: Straßenfest
Description:
A computer shop-owner was found in his shop in a pool of blood. Who is the murder from the street party?

All players (4 male, 5 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

Name: Fußball: Fieber
Description:
One soccer star is kidnapped, and the kidnapper has killed people as well. Who hates Soccer enough to do this at the World Cup?

All players (5 male, 6 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer

Name: Geburtstagsparty
Description:
Frida has her birthday party, and her sister gets sick and goes to the bathroom.  When they check on her later, she's found in a pool of blood. What's happening here?

All players (9 male, 3 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

Name: Hochzeit Mattenklotz
Description:
Jürgen and Colette are getting married today, but just before the ceremony Colette disappears. Where is she?

All players (4 male, 4 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer.

Name: Mord im Leuchtturm
Description:
Frank Mohn was found dead in this room.  Who of the other hotel gusts knows more that the others?

All players (7 male, 4 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer

Name: WIM
Description:
"the every which way word game" (tm)

Players compete to score the most points by forming interlocking words in all directions, using square letter tiles, most of which can be used in more than one direction or as more than one letter.

WIM consists of 96 letter tiles, tile racks, and a letter bag. There is no board.

There are 19 distinct tiles which make the 26 letters plus the blank tile. Eight of the tiles are ambiguous and can be read as two different letters, depending on orientation. For example, an upside-down A is a V, and a sideways N is a Z. Three of the tiles may be used as the same letter in more than one orientation (O, S, and X). A tile may be used as different letters in different words at the same time, even in the same play.

Each letter has a different value and scores are calculated according to the letter played. Players receive bonuses for using a previously-played tile as a letter it wasn't used as previously, for changing the orientation of a word, or for using all seven tiles on their rack in a single play.

Home Page: http://www.puzzazz.com/wim

Name: Proverbial Wisdom Junior
Description: This is a simplified version of Proverbial Wisdom. There are three types of challenges for players: try to sketching, acting or define a saying. Comes with a spinner, card tray with sketch cards, picture cards and definition cards, clue hider, timer and sketch board. The first team to collect three of each card type wins.
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: Seven Horses of the Redfly Sacred Circle
Description: This unique product will help your child to develop a respect for and understanding of Native American life. Contents include a carrying pouch, seven horses of the RedFly Sacred Circle game, colored paper, twelve star stones, one medicine wheel, numerical playing cards, instruction sheet and other pieces. Collect one of each colored teepee place cards as you travel around the Red Fly Sacred Circle. It is a cooperative game. The game is completed as a team effort with all players participating. The game ends when the last star stone is placed.

Name: Toads of Fun
Description: Players move their toads around the lily pond catching flies based on matching a color and a number on the spinner to the same color and number on the lily pads.  Analytical thinking skills are used when players control the bumblebee and get to consider different possible places to put the bee and what consequence each possible choice might have. This game includes six toads, 36 flies, one bee, and a board with two spinners, game board showing pond with lily pads, SPLASH spots and logs.

Name: Kick-Off Soccer
Description:
The field is laid out on a 30 by 21 grid. Play alternates between the Offense and the Defense. The ball is advanced by passing dribbling and heading. When a defensive man is within specific distances from the ball and attempt can be made to tackle or intercept. The result is determined by throwing a die, but strategic placement of the men can affect the odds. Goal tries are similarly determined by die throws adjusted to the positioning of the goalkeeper and other defensive players.

From Designer's Notes:
KICK-OFF Soccer has been developed to follow as closely as possible the real game of soccer.  The strategy and tactics are the same, as are most of the rules.  Soccer is not a complicated game.  There are very few set plays, these mainly arise on Corners, Free-Kicks and Throw-Ins.  The game is played through with the skills, flair and innovation of individual players working together as a team.  And so with "KICK-OFF", by using simple Basic Moves, the flair and innovation has been left up to the individual player.
After playing one or two games of "KICK-OFF", the method of play becomes easy and only brief reference is necessary to player and ball movement, and die throws.  The die throws do not determine the outcome of the game, they merely simulate the chances played in real soccer.
"KICK-OFF" has been play tested by enthusiastic "youngsters" aged from eleven to adult.  For the young enthusiasts, some adult assistance was found advisable at first, but once advised, they were at home with "KICK-OFF" as they were on the real field!

Name: Ticket to Ride: USA 1910
Description:
Ticket to Ride: USA 1910 is a card expansion for the original Ticket to Ride boardgame, winner of the 2004 Spiel des Jahres. It contains 181 large format cards (the same size as Ticket to Ride: Europe and Ticket to Ride: MÃ¤rklin).  This includes 35 new 1910 Destination Tickets, a GlobeTrotter Bonus card for completing the most tickets, 4 Mystery Train Destination Tickets originally provided in the Ticket to Ride: Mystery Train Expansion expansion, and a complete replacement deck of the 141 cards from the original game deck (30 Destination Tickets (4 cards have a reduced value from Ticket to Ride), 110 Train Cards, and 1 Longest Route Bonus Card (Trans America Express)).

The rulebook is from the original game designer Alan R. Moon that gives you three additional different ways to play the game:

     The 1910 Rules: Played as the standard Ticket to Ride, but using only the 1910 Destination Tickets, and GlobeTrotter Bonus card.
     The Big Cities Rules: Played with only the newly identified 35 "Big City" Destination Tickets (15 Standard Tickets, 19 1910 Tickets, and 1 Mystery Train Ticket).
     The Mega Game: featuring all of the game's Destination Tickets and Bonus Cards (30 Standard Tickets, 35 1910 Tickets, 4 Mystery Train Tickets, and both Bonus cards).


Part of Ticket to Ride series.

Name: Felsberger Tara
Description: Tara is the newest Felsberger game and follows in their tradition of well-made wooden dexterity games. The games uses a color-sided die used to select pieces that are manipulated on the playing surface. A blend of strategy and dexterity.

Name: POTS! The Game
Description: Set in Classical Athens, players bid against each other to acquire the biggest and best collection of vases, as they travel round the key areas of the city. Good judgment and a pinch of luck are needed, but even then the gods of Mount Olympus may intervene to help or hinder you. [Taken from the game's website.]

Name: Sudoku Dice
Description: A multi-player game based on the popular Sudoku puzzles. Players roll dice to show which numbers can be placed on the common grid. Numbers must be placed within legal Sudoku guidelines. Cards are used to re-arrange tiles and force other events. Players score each time they can complete a row, column, or box. A variant allows players to identify if a placement would cause the puzzle to become unsolvable.

Name: Sequenz
Description:
The game has 4 sets of 20 thick wooden tiles in 4 colors, which are numbered from 1-20. The 4x5 fields of the board also show the numbers 1-20.

Object of the game is to score the most points, but these points are given at the end of the game only! The game ends when all 80 tiles are placed on the board, but only the top tiles are valued; adjacent tiles of the same color give bonus points.

To reduce the influence of luck, the hand of 10 tiles is not filled randomly, but can be taken from 10 open tiles. Anyway, it's a game where you need a good memory, because you should remember which tiles have been played already and thus can't help you getting some bonus points.

This game is very easy to learn and play, but it's not so easy to find the best strategy.

Name: Dynamite
Description:
snip from introduction:
"  The Draw-Place deck face down in center of table.  Each player draws one card at a time.  First one to draw a dynamite card is the dealer.

The Deal-The cars are dealt one at a time beginning at left.  With two players,  deal seven cards to each.  After all hands are dealt,  dealer turns up the top card and leaves the deck face down beside it.

Object of Play-To get rid of all cards in your hand.  the first player to succeed wins that round and the others must record their score according to the cards left in their hand."

As the name implies,  their are rock,  scissors,  and paper cards.  In addition,  there are dynamite and double take cards,  all of which come in assorted colors.

The short of it is,  think Rock Scissors Paper meets Uno.

Name: Busy Busy Builder
Description:
From the box:
Busy Busy Builder is a dress-up game for boys and girls who love building things! Be the busiest builder in town by collecting your own matching colored set of tools: screwdriver, hammer, wrench, nut and bolt.  Don't work too fast because you might land on a Sore thumb.  the first player to collect all of his or her tools and the Tool Belt wins the game.

Contents:
4 Moving bolts
4 Screwdrivers
4 Hammers
4 Wrenches
4 Nuts
4 Bolts
1 Sore thumb
1 Screwdriver spinner arrow
1 Tool Belt
1 Game Board
Instructions

Ages 3+

Name: Three-Player Crokinole
Description:
Three-Player Crokinole is a specially designed Crokinole board that works only with three. This game cannot be played on a standard board and thus is considered to be a different game.

The three-player board has markings that divide the board into three areas (vs four for a standard board), and repositions the pegs around the center to make these three positions optimal for shooting. Three players play independently (no partners), and when shooting either other player's disk must be hit for your shot to be legal. Scoring is done on a differences basis as in the original game, except often two people will score per turn as a result.

Name: Five-Hole Crokinole
Description:
Five-Hole Crokinole is played on a specially-drilled board and was popular in Canada in the late 1800s. The board is sized like a standard board, but in addition to the center hole it has a hole in the center of each 10-point area.

Play is similar to standard Crokinole, except that any disk pocketed in one of the 10-point area holes is removed from play and counts -10 points. This allows for both offensive attack and makes tricky shots more risky. As a result, scoring is usually more chaotic and variable.

This game can be bought in five-hole form, or often a standard board can be retrofitted to make this version. That retrofit is almost always one-way, though!

Name: Viking Waves
Description:
Viking Waves takes place in the areas raided and conquered by the Norwegian and Danish Vikings during the early Viking Age. It's a game primarily for two players, though limited solitaire play is also possible. The various Viking chieftains rarely fought each other directly, so players compete indirectly.

The game is divided into three phases, each of which involves dozens of raids/attacks and which can be played as a separate game (or all three can be played sequentially as a campaign). In Phase 1, which lasts from 792 until around 834, each raid involves a few ships and lasts only a few days. In Phase 2, from around 834 to around 850–864, raids are larger. In Phase 3, from around 850–864 until 879, the goal is conquering land with armies and creating permanent settlements.

In the standard game, each player represents an ever-changing group of Norwegian and Danish chieftains. Optional rules allow for the historical division of territory between Norwegian and Danish groups, allow for limited combat between the two players, and provide for solitaire play.

One twelve-page rulebook
Two 8.5" x 11" maps
One Player Display
342 counters

Name: Inword
Description: Players try to guess the word after they given a cryptic clue and the Inword, a series of consecutive letters within the word they are trying to guess. In turn, each player tries to guess the other letters contained in the target word. Players take turns as guessers and host.

Name: Giant Dice
Description: A set of giant dice are rolled and depending on the type of arithmetic operations allowed in the game, players do math involving the numbers to match corresponding numbers on their sheet. The first player to get a row of 4 or 5 numbers wins.

Name: Jutland
Description:
Jutland: 2 Player Card Game sim of the great Sea Battle of WWI. German vs British Fleets. Each side gets a Unique deck. Played in 6 "Historical" turns. Players try to get the highest scoring hand each turn. Good Filler game. Complete Ruleset and Cardset at: 
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Jutland.html

Name: Sesame Street Simple Shapes Game
Description:
Oscar the Grouch, Cookie Monster, and Ernie face off in this slightly atypical memory matching game.  Each player's goal is to have the longest chain of tiles at game end.

There are two notable differences from most memory matching games.  
1. Rather than two tiles being matched to each other, this game has players matching tiles to the symbol resulting from a spinner
2. Instead of ending when all tiles are matched, the game ends when the fourth stop tile is drawn.

Twenty-nine tiles are laid face-down on the play surface.  These tiles interlock like puzzle pieces, making a chain of tiles when credited to a player.  The game includes a spinner with, six spaces.  Three of the spinner spaces show one shape (triangle, circle, or square), while the other three spaces have two shapes.  Players take turns using the spinner, and then selecting one tile.

If the tile says "free spin", then the tile is added to that player's chain, and the player immediately takes an additional turn.

If the tile matches the shape(s) on the spinner, then the tile is added to the player's chain of tiles, and that player's turn ends.

If the tile does not match the shape on the spinner, the tile is shown to the other players, and then returned face-down to the available tiles.

If the tile says "stop", then it is attached to the top of the spinner.  When the fourth "stop" tile is drawn, the game ends.

Name: A History of Chess
Description:
H.J.R. Murray's classic work on the history of chess includes chess variants from around the world and throughout history.

Originally published in 1913, it was recently reprinted and is now available again.

Contains history, development and the rules of nearly every Chess variant prior to 1900. A Classic!

Republished by Oxford University Press (available from Amazon et al)

Name: Sesame Street Dominoes
Description:
Sesame Street Dominoes is played like the classic game Dominoes with variations for ages 3 and up and ages 4 and up.  The dominoes are thick cardboard pieces with the faces of popular Sesame Street characters in the center surrounded by 4 different colors to the top, bottom, left and right.

In the 3 and up game, players match the faces of Sesame Street characters.  In the 4 and up game, players match colors.

Name: Rotten Wood: Horror Rules Mini-Game #1
Description:
There's something rotten in the woods tonight - and it ain't your franks and beans! The dead are on the move, and it's up to you to put a stop to it. So grab your shotgun, fire up the chainsaw and get ready for some good old-fashioned zombie-hunting... Horror Rules style!

Horror Rules Mini-Games provide all the fun and mayhem of Horror Rules without the rule crunching. Included in this Mini-Game is everything you need to play, including Paper Forge Minis, maps, weapons and item counters and more - just print and go. Use the more than 60 Horror Markers to simulate the challenges, dangers, perils and scares of the zombie-infested woods, and change the mix to make a different game every time. You pick the size, scope, number of pieces and even the goal of each game.

The Horror Rules Mini-Game system is flexible and fully customizable, great for veteran gamers, kids, families, parties or as a way to introduce new players to the wonders of gaming. Play it solo or with others in cooperative or head-to-head play. Games take as little as 5 minutes and can easily be played during a coffee break or lunch time. With endless variations and Styles of Play, you can create whatever gaming environment you like, from a simple tabletop boardgame to a full-blown RPG.

Rotten Wood is packed with full-color gaming aids that bring the zombie nightmare alive. Inside you'll find:


     Paper Forge Character Minis: 6 complete Characters, each with Stats and Skills



     Paper Forge Bad Guy Minis: a full page of fearsome zombies, complete with Stats and Powers



     Map of Rotten Wood: 8 pages of maps; use them alone or together to build a master map



     Horror Markers: More than 60 counters packed with challenges, hazards, weapons, items, perils and frights



     Rule Spins: A dozen Spin cards to add endless variation and spice to your Mini-Game



     Bad Guy Power-Ups: Jack up your Bad Guys with these disgusting but guaranteed-to-please boosters



     Rules: All the instructions you need to make the mayhem happen


Paper Forge Character and Bad Guy Minis are fully compatible with Horror Rules the RPG, with Stats and Skills printed right on the back. Use them to play the Mini-Game, the full RPG or any other modern roleplaying game. The 8-pg map can be used in HR as well or whatever game you choose.

Included in this download are two complete sets of rules, enough to fit every taste:

The Basic Rules are a quick, simple board game with fast setup, plenty of action and thrills and tremendous variation. Use the Horror Markers to make every game exciting and different. Play by yourself or with a pal.

The Skirmish Rules are full-out tabletop war. Pit your heroic and resourceful characters against the not-so-heroic and ravenous zombies in a knock-down drag-out no-holds-barred free-for-all in Rotten Wood. Skirmish Markers include standard Horror Rules weapons with full Horror Rules stats. Requires two to play.

Name: The Bird-Table Game
Description:
"Find out how to identify the birds in YOUR garden!"

In this game, players move around the board collecting points by correctly identifying and answering questions about wild birds that might be found in British gardens. Although prior knowledge helps, it's not essential: the game is designed to help players develop their bird-related expertise.

Name: Racecraze
Description:
"RACECRAZE:  A Strategic, Fun-Filled Racing Game!"

A Nascar-like themed racing game from a small publisher. The mechanics of this game are simple: "Qualifying" position is based on random card draw. Each turn, roll three (standard) dice, and optionally roll two more "special dice" (33% +3, 33% -3, 33% take a card). Move your car on the track (16 spaces to 20 spaces around from inside to outside track; no track "choke points") by the total amount. Cards either move car forward, backward, or force player "into the pit" before proceeding. Player turn order is re-ranked each turn by position+laps, and each race (of 5) ends after a predetermined number of laps.

Each player is awarded a number of points at the conclusion of each race based on finishing position. Winner has the most points after the fifth race.

Name: Tank Killers
Description: Two player card game. Simulates a battle between two tank formations during WW2. The current version of the game has decks for: Germans, British, and Americans circa 1944-5. Rules and card set available at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/TanK.html

Name: High Iron
Description: High Iron is a very early Winsome game with an extremely limited print run. It is Colorado-based train game with idea that were further and better developed in later Winsome titles.

Name: Gametasia
Description: GAMETASIA CARDS 71 boxed cards featuring 47 Extractors, 9 Utopians, 9 Treasure Cards, and 6 Rules Cards. 2 to 4 players.

Name: Royal Poker Dice Game
Description:
Royal Poker Dice Game is a game of Yahtzee using the entire deck of cards.
Five 12-sided dice use all 52 cards of a normal deck plus 8 stars (wild cards). Every possible poker hand can be made.
For one or more players.

Contents: Five 12 sided Dice, Dice Cup, Score Pad, Felt Mat, Convenient Carry Case.

A less expensive "travel" version is available which eliminates the felt mat, changes the shape of the dice cup to oblong, and replaces the carry case with a fabric drawstring bag.

Name: The World's Greatest Travel Game
Description:
Two containers hold 25 3 dimensional one-inch cubes each.  The cubes have pictures numbered 1-5 on all of their sides except one, which holds a large red X on it.

The object of the game is to to acquire five X's in a row, like a bingo game.  However, this game is much more complex in its variant forms.

Initially, the base setup is for each person to turn all of their picture cubes to the 1 numbered picture--the easiest items to spot.  Goal: Spot five items or a picture of each of the five items, revealing 5 X's which form a straight line.

Rise To The Top:  In this variant, each person does not reveal the X upon sighting a 1 numbered item.  Instead, the person will turn the number two picture to the top.  This continues until the number three item is sighted, and the X is turned up.  The first person to five X's in a row wins.

Go For Points:  Similar to Above.  Attach a time limit or mileage limit to the game.  At game end, total the numbers of the photos as points, scoring each X as a 10 point item.  Highest total wins.

This can be played as a solo variant, with a solo player trying to accomplish point goals per number of miles, or trip duration.

The Handicapper:  In a child versus adult game, using the base game rules, the adult would adjust their numbered pictures to a 4 or 5 starting point.

One Block At A Time:  Start with all X's showing.  Each person will take out the first block in their container.  As soon as either player sees one of the five items, they replace the block in their container with the picture showing of the item spotted.  They then move on to their next block, until all 25 blocks are gone through.

The game ends when one person is done with all 25 blocks.  Total all points of exposed pictures.

Get Nasty:  Each player arranges the cubes of their opponent, using the number five pictures of each number (5-5's, 5'4's, etc...) and arranges them in a way which is thought to be most difficult to achieve 5 in a row.  Same as base game otherwise.

Composite Game:  Start with all number 1's.  As you see each item, turn that cube over to X.  When you get five X's in a row, turn that row over to the number two pictures.  Continue with the same goals, turning five in a row over at a time until you get the five numbered pictures.  The first person to turn over five number five pictures, revealing the final X's, wins.  A complicated variant, indeed.

Name: El gran juego de Conocer la Ciencia
Description:
A Spanish Trivial pursuit clone, Science themed.
The 5 categories are:
 - Nature
 - Space & Technology
 - Characters
 - Science history
 - Other Sciences

Name: Post Office
Description: This is a game for 2 to 4 players. The instructions say that it should be played by girls and boys together. Each player gets a particular color to start on. That color is used later on. A girl starts the game! There are spaces on the gameboard such as First Class, Air Mail or Special Delivery. When a player lands on one of them the player picks a card and reads it aloud. The card will list some kind of stunt that must be accomplished in order to score points. If a partner is needed to accomplish the stunt then the player spins a spinner, the male who has that color representing him is the girls partner for the stunt. There is a time limit to accomplish each stunt. The stunts are childish (this game is appropriate for perhaps 8 to 12 year olds).  Some examples of stunts that need to be done;  You and your partner eat a potato chip at the same time and immediately whistle Yankee Doodle. First one to whistle the first line wins the points. Or Standing back to back with your partner, remove his or her jacket or sweater and put it on yourself without turning around. The successful completion of a stunt in the given time limit results in winning a certain amount of points. First player to reach 500 points is the winner.
Families: Theme: Mail / Stamps / The Post Office

Name: Skipper: Barbie's Little Sister
Description: This is a game about Skipper (Barbie's younger sister) and her horse Prince. Appropriate for 6 to 10 year olds. It is a simple roll and move game. The object of the game is to be the person who reaches the BEST IN SHOW square at the center of the board while holding; a card for your horse Prince, your tack, your riding habit, your club pin and 25 points . Players roll and move around the board. On some spots on the board you will be given the opportunity to enter the SHOW RING and score points for how your horse does. Those points can be traded in for some of what you need. Necessary money is accumulated as you go around the squares on the board.

Name: Spion
Description:
Spion (=Spy) is a 2-player strategy game with an unusual victory condition: you must find two hidden points on the opponents half of the gameboard. These hidden points are secretly marked on a paper copy of the gameboard; a whole pad of copies is included.

The gameboard has 2 halves of 64 hex-fields each and the armies of the 2 players contain 6 defenders, 4 little spies and 2 big spies. The defenders are single colored, while the spies show both colors, because they can be turned over when captured! Defenders cannot leave their half of the board. Spies can move everywhere and they are therefore needed to find the 2 hidden points.

Name: Flip & Flop
Description:
The board is 8x8 in size and every player has 4 playing pieces. Object of the game is to move 2 of the 4 pieces on the opposing side of the board.

The name of the game comes from the moving mechanism of the playing pieces: they can move 1 field in all 4 directions, but they are flipped over every time when they move (I guess they "flop" when moving to the left or right side).

All playing pieces are numbered from 1-4 on one side and from 5-8 on the other side. Since the pieces are always flipped over, the value of the pieces is changing with every move and it needs much thinking in advance to find the best moves.

Another problem is, that the pieces should always look in the same direction. To assure this, each piece has 2 dots on the front and 2 on the back, but when comparing the pieces on the game-box with the ones included with this game, it is obvious, that this designing problem is not solved very well.

Name: Murmel Fiff
Description:
Taken directly from the translated rules

"Murmel Fiff" is the name of the friendly marmot, who organizes a fun apple harvest with its friends: On the marmot hill stands a strange apple tree, whose bright glowing fruits have different colors-exactly like the marmots.  Each one especially loves the apples of its color and wants to add these four to the stock in its own hole.

(I love this bit)

Whoever will manage it the first? Whoever gathers diligently at the beginning; and in the second phase, with the luck of the dice and foresight, gives away apples, pinches them and brings them back to safety, which influences the exciting race.

In any case you have only won, if the marmot has all four of its own apples-and only those-in its own hole and then also places itself in it!

Ages 5 and up.

Name: Adopt-A-Dog
Description:
From the rules:
Take home your new best friend!  In Adopt-A-Dog, every player gets a chance to adopt and nurture a lovable puppy.  Once players sort through the dogs' items and collect 3 of their dogs' favorite toys, players can take home and care for their new pets!

For ages 3+

Adopt-A-Dog is a VERY simple set-collection and trading game for very young children.  It plays fast and is easy for young children to learn.  I would not suggest this game for children over 6 as they will get bored very quickly.

Name: Chuckers
Description: Each player's side of the board consists of 9 panels in a 3x3 grid which all start as one player's color (orange or yellow) but become the other player's color when the panel is flipped. This can be done by landing a marble on a panel, causing the panel to flip and change color. Players attempt to get 6 panels in a row of their color by quickly and repeatedly launching marbles onto the game board.

Name: Robo Bash
Description: A free game included in the Dork Tower #14 comic book. Each player controls a RoboBasher (mechanical vehicles with differing attributes in Firepower, Armor, and Speed), moving it around an arena trying to destroy all the other RoboBashers. During each round, a player can use a limited number of "Power Dice" to boost the values of their RoboBasher's attributes.

Name: Make-A-Scene
Description:
Info from back of box:

Set the scene for laughter and fun with Make A Scene, the uproarious Category Drawing Game! Start with a deserted main street, or an unused barnyard, or maybe a bare bedroom. Now draw as many items you can think of into the scene before time runs out. Here’s the catch - each item must begin with the same letter and must really belong in the scene.

The drawing is exciting, but get ready for real laughs when it comes time to justify your choices. Go ahead... explain what the MERMAID is doing on MAIN STREET next to the MAILMAN and the MUTT!

Scoring: 
A team receives one point for each item drawn and two points if the item is unique (drawn by only one team). After 4 rounds, the team with the highest score wins.

For 2 players or 2 teams.

Name: Action Dragon
Description:
This is a game of sentence construction "cunningly educational!"

The object of the game is to reach the "circle 9" by discarding all his cards. Players advance on the board by making sentences with the Action Dragon cards.

How to play:
Each players draws a card when on their turn, to advance, the player must set on the table a series of cards that contain at least the number of cards indicated on the next circle you want to reach. This series must also include at least one card of each of the colors indicated by the triangles on the next circle. The series of cards (image) makes up a sentence that the player must say out loud.

There is a variant for youngsters.

Name: Healthy Habits
Description:
From Dr. Toy:

"Players will have a blast moving around the game as they are the game pieces. The set comes with 30 cards that use the topics of nutrition, exercise, sleep and personal hygiene. The game doesn't have a board. Rather, the cards can be set up in any pattern you wish, winding around the room, under tables, in and out of doors, etc. The children move forward by rolling the large foam dice included in the game. For example, "You rode your bike, move ahead three spaces.", and "You sat in front of the TV set all day and didn't get any exercise, move back to the square." This educational game is a great way to promote the values of good nutrition, exercise, healthy sleep habits and personal hygiene."

Name: The Fund-Raising Game
Description:
snip from rules:

"Object:  The object of this game is to set a fund raising goal and raise that amount of money.  There are intervening factors,  such as luck and timing,  that will affect the raising of your dollar goal.  However,  the bottom line is cash on hand.  
   The game is not intended to be competitive.  The main objective is to provide discussion among players on various aspects of fund raising."

The game consists of a game board,  4 tokens,  2 dice,  25 each of Risk and Opportunity cards,  a pack of Fund raising Goal and Funds Balance cards,  play money,  Rules booklet and ANSWER KEY.

Yes,  ANSWER KEY!  Basically,  this is a game designed to teach fund raising skills to young 'wannabe' fund raisers.  So the cards have real questions on them.  For instance, "15.  To generate significantly more income from mail appeals,  a priority would be to . . . A.  Mail more times in a year   B.  use segmentation data to specialize appeals.   C.  purge lapsed donors to trim your mailing expenses."

And in case you really wanted to know,  according to the answer key,  the answer is . . .  B

Name: Drag Racing, The Board Game
Description:
Publisher's descriptions:

"Drag racing fun for the entire family with DRAG RACING-the Board Game. Don't let rain dates get you down. Now you can drag race anytime, anywhere. In the trailer or at home on the kitchen table, drag racing action like you have seen at the track. Our game is played with dice and charts. We've included plastic game pieces in the shape of dragsters, funny cars, and pro stockers. You can match race or qualify a 16 car field and run through eliminations. But watch out for the racing gremlins. Blown motors, broken transmissions, tire shake, or smoking the tires are just some of the problems you might run into on our track."

". . . you can race in a Top Fuel Dragster, Nitro Funny Car, or in a Pro Stocker."

"Want to be the number 1 qualifier? Run in 'power' for a shot at 'low e.t.' Watch out though, you might smoke the tires, grenade a motor, or get out of the groove. Tire shake or a broken blower might also do you in. With a little luck you can make a clean pass on your way to victory. Great fun for the entire family. You can re-create your favorite drag racing event or start your own 'fantasy' series with "DRAG RACING - The Board Game."

"There are three ways to play the game.
       1. Match Racing (two out of three) is the quickest.
       2. Running a set field of 8 or 16 cars through eliminations.
       3. Qualify a 16 car field then run through eliminations."

"The Drag Racing Game Co. brings drag racing to your table top with a new 3-D game board. Our new drag strip game board is easy to read, has full length guardrails, and comes in full color!!!"

"Game comes complete with 3 piece game board, 12 plastic game pcs.(cars), 4 die, ladder charts to track eliminations, and all the charts you need to race down the quarter mile."

Name: Alphacadabra
Description: Try to locate the hidden word of your opponent, as in a game of Battleship. Then try to find what is that word by naming letters, as in a game of Hangman.

Name: Don't Quote Me: Sports Illustrated Edition
Description: Players attempt to move their piece around the track the fastest, answering questions from five different categories from the realm of sports: Team, individual, vintage, names & numbers, and sidelines.  Players may have to identify quotations, pick three correct answers out of four, list items, and answer other trivia questions.   Covers a wide range of sports questions, including even TV shows, movies, and obscure sports.

Name: Galactic Expanse: Starship Battles
Description:
Publisher's description:

This is an exciting card game of strategy, tactics and chance in deep space combat between the warring space-faring humanoid species who all feel that the galaxy is not big enough for all of them. Their starships combine the awesome firepower of powerful particle accelerator beam energy weapons and devastating hyper-speed torpedoes for close combats and long-range raids by smaller ship-borne strike craft and the deadly mercenary shadowcraft. The four different species can ally in various patterns, resulting in different combinations in different games, or they can operate alone. Players determine when and where to seek battles; to launch distant raids or close with the enemy for battles within star systems or nebulae. The side that scores the most victory points by vaporizing enemy ships and winning star systems wins the game. This is an entertaining and fun card game where every playing is different. Playing time is one to three hours.

Name: Mergers & Acquisitions: The Hostile Takeover Game
Description:
In this game, you become a business owner attempting to increase your company's profits through hostile takeovers of other companies. You have investment money of 1.2 billion dollars to finance your coming mergers and acquisitions.

Your goal is to buy other companies at a relatively low price compared to their value. If you control that company, your company's profits will increase as well.

The basics of the game:

There is one more business than there are the number of players, each with different company values. Players each have 14 chips with investment values printed on them (4 X 5, 3 X 10, 3 X 50, 1 X 100, 1 X 200, 1 X 300, 1 X 400). They (usually) secretly place these one at a time near a business they wish to invest in. The 2nd, 5th, and some later investments made in each company are made publicly (everyone sees the investment amount).

Players gain control of a company by having more invested in the company at the end of the game than any of the other players (and get more points for having more than all the other players combined). The tricky part being that a player will almost always need to have control of 2 or more business to win, but there's not enough businesses to be able to do so easily, so each player *will* have to out-invest another player, which involves bluffing them as to where your high-value investment chips are.

Each player also chooses an 'investment strategy' card at the beginning of the game, and plays it at some point during the game, changing things like making the value of a company halved, or giving them extra shares in a company, etc.

Name: Champion of the East
Description:
Also known as 'Conquerors of the Eastern Country'.

A 2-6 player game set in feudal Eastern Japan(2-12 players if combined with Heroes of Western Japan).

Meant to appeal to fans of the many feudal multi-player games that came out in the 80s in Japan and of 'eurogame' fans wanting something quicker.

It ends up playing like a fast-paced 'History of the World'. Not in the 'multiple epoch' sense (the game does not cover multiple eras), but in the sense that attacks are done by 'expanding out' and attacking adjacent territories with newly hired units, and a placed unit is never actually moved.

Each player controls a different daimyo, each having tis own unique (and fairly important / useful) power.

There is a deck of Fate cards that give valuable bonuses and abilities to the players that get them. Players bid each turn on the right to get 1st pick of the available cards that turn.

Money is received from territories, varying in value from 1 to 3 per territory.
Gold is spent buying the 3 main types of armies can be hired to attack with, bidding for card choice, and paying to maintain the effects of 'continuing cards'

Victory is done by getting a point per territory held at the end of the game, with bonus points (or penalties) given for tea bowls placed in various territories throughout the game. The catch is that only the player who placed each tea bowl knows its value (and thereby, how important it is to get/retain control of that territory).

It's a DTP game, meaning that you need to stick the counters on your own blank counters.

This can be combined with Heroes of Western Japan to get a larger game covering all of Japan.

Name: Heroes of Western Japan
Description:
Also known as 'Heroes of the Western Country'.

A 2-6 player game set in feudal Western Japan (2-12 players if combined with Champion of the East).

Meant to appeal to fans of the many feudal multiplayer games that came out in the 80's in Japan and of 'eurogame' fans wanting something quicker.

It ends up playing like a fast-paced 'History of the World'. Not in the 'multiple epoch' sense (the game does not cover multiple eras), but in the sense that attacks are done by 'expanding out' and attacking adjacent territories with newly hired units, and a placed unit is never actually moved.

Each player controls a different daimyo, each having tis own unique (and fairly important / useful) power.

There is a deck of Fate cards that give valuable bonuses and abilities to the players that get them. Players bid each turn on the right to get 1st pick of the available cards that turn.

Money is received from territories, varying in value from 1 to 3 per territory.
Gold is spent buying the 3 main types of armies can be hired to attack with, bidding for card choice, and paying to maintain the effects of 'continuing cards'

Victory is done by getting a point per territory held at the end of the game, with bonus points (or penalties) given for tea bowls placed in various territories throughout the game. The catch is that only the player who placed each teabowl knows its value (and thereby, how important it is to get/retain control fo that territory).

It's a DTP game, meaning that you need to stick the counters on your own blank counters.

This can be combined with Champion of the East to get a larger game covering all of Japan.

Name: Hockeyswap!
Description:
(From the Back of the Box: Build a hockey dynasty through ruthless trading and brilliant coaching. Blow away the competition during regular season games and qualify for the playoffs. Win the playoffs and become League Champion!)

Players are coaches of hockey teams that fill up their rosters by either a blind draw of player cards, or coaches can draft players based on an $8,000,000 salary cap.

The regular season games are determined by drawing discs out of a bag, and comparing either the offensive or defensive ranks of the players to determine who scores a goal, or goals, for that period. Follow the supplied season schedule, or create one of your own, and play through the regular season and the playoffs to determine the champion.

Name: L'Enclos
Description: An abstract strategy game first published in Vers l'Éducation Nouvelle n° 402, April 1986.  Each player has three sheep: on a turn, a player moves one sheep to an adjacent hex and then places one barrier between any two adjacent hexes.  The first player to be blocked in and unable to move loses.

Name: Flibid-e-Jib
Description:
What's a Flib? What's a Jib? And why am I trying to lose all my cards again!

Flibid-e-Jib is the wacky new card game that's not only hours of fun for the whole family, but educational too! (sshh! Don't tell the kids!)

For 2-6 players age 7 and up, Flibid-e-Jib is an addictive way to make a rainy day go by quickly! Perfect for the cottage or trip.

Instructions in French and Spanish.

Name: About Nothing
Description:
About Nothing, The Absurd Game of Useless Trivia is the latest game from Brainy Day Games.

Here's some of the nothing you'll find inside: 
- Absurd World Facts 
- History of Plumbing 
- 80's Cartoons 
- Ancient Sports 
- Crazy Inventors 
- Fast Food Facts 
- Sesame Street Trivia 
- Word Origins 
- Parts of the Body 
- Elvis Knowledge

1800 Questions. 
2-6 Players. 
For ages 7 and up. 
Lots of useless trivia.

Name: Housebuilder
Description: The Housebuilder game is based on the reality of house building. 2-4 players may play. All players start with a 10,000 pound overdraft limit. From "Start" proceed along the board,  in turn, collecting money to buy building plots and stage build your own home. Each time you pass "Start" you should select a "Builders Credit" card from the pile and collect the amount stated on the card. The first player to successfully complete a house wins the game.

Name: Disqualified!
Description:
Disqualified! is the new driving board game from Tucker Enterprises which uses movement around the board is not determined by the throw of a dice, but as a result of the speed you choose to drive, combined with the effect of various hazards and the ever present possibility of being stopped by a Police car.

You are racing against your opponents to be the first to complete a journey of 500 miles. The player driving the Police car however has a different objective: To win he/she must endorse everyone else's license with 12 penalty points and Disqualify them from the game.

Name: The Game of Pony Express
Description: This is a roll and move game based on the Pony Express. The goal of the game is be the last person with money left in the game.

Name: Ranger Rick and the Great Forest Fire
Description: This is a roll and move game using a spinner. Players compete to be the first to get to the fire so that they can put it out. There are event cards that can come into play from landing on a particular space or from the spinner.

Name: Huhuuh
Description:
In this cooperative game, the players try to help the ghosts get back to their castles before the sun rises.  Each player controls at least one ghost of each color, depending on the number of players.  A roll of the die will indicate what the current player must do.  Red, green, or blue indicates that the same color of ghost may go home.  White allows the player to select the ghost to send home.  Black requires the player to take a ghost out of a castle.  Yellow adds a ray to the sun, progressing toward the end of the game.

Game setup is scaled for the number of players.

Ages 4+

Name: Carcassonne: Kreivi ja Kuningas
Description:
Carcassonne - Kreivi ja Kuningas (English: The Count & the King) is a compilation of three small expansions — The River II, The Count of Carcassonne and King & Scout — for the game Carcassonne. It was packaged in a standard-size Carcassonne expansion box and only released in Finland. It is a precursor to Hans im Glück's expansion Count, King & Consort which used the same compilation components but also including a new expansion, The Cult, and removed the Scout since that expands Carcassonne: Hunters & Gatherers.

Part of the Carcassonne series.

Name: Trafalgar 1805. Héroes e imperios en la encrucijada
Description:
This game uses a simulation system ("Navíos de línea") to recreate naval combat in the period from 1740 to 1815, both at a tactic and strategic level. In the tactical system players control individual ships on a blue grid. In the strategic system, players control squads on an board showing all the Atlantic.

WARNING: All game components are in Spanish!

The tactical game used to recreate the naval battle of Trafalgar uses the following sequence:
1. Determine initiative
2. Combat: First, the player with the initiative fires cannons, and then the player without the initiative (although damage is applied simultaneously)
3. Movement: First the player without the initiative, then the one with it.
4. Crew actions and surrender: Boardings, Sinkings and Surenders are resolved.

The strategic game uses another sequence:
1. Initiative
2. Meteorology: Climate and Wind
3. Strategic Movement: Squad composition, Sightings, Persecutions
4. Tactical Movement
5. Adjustment phase: delay of strategic orders.
6. Repairs

Included in the box are:
-Rigid Gameboard (126 x 64 cm), printed on both sides for tactical and strategic maps.
-60 cardboard figures of the ships that participated in the battle.
-180 sails to be mounted on the ships (plus 24 extras)
-Historical Notes which include a replay of the historical battle.
-Rules of play and 150 cardboard mounted markers.
-60 plastic bases for the ships, a vane, and a 6 sided die.

More information on www.deltaediciones.com

Name: Country Trains
Description:
The idea for country trains came when the designer was playing Kings Gate one evening. The rectangular tiles could be stations and the tiles around them and joining them could be services and track. This was way back in 2006.

Over the years the design has been revisited many times and the game developed.

On a turn a player must lay a tile and may move their train. If the train is on connection between two stations it must move back to a station to re-coal. If the train is at a station, it may move onto a track connection to make a delivery. Deliveries are payed out based on the goods at the source and the type in demand at the destination (timber, sheep, ore). All stations have spaces for goods to be delivered too. When these are full, that station can receive no more goods. However, space can be made for more goods by delivering passengers.

The tiles players lay represent track, which they are paid to lay (land grant railway style). Country tiles which provide goods for carriage. Plus passengers which consume the carried goods as described above.

The game also has station tiles which are owned by the players. Players start with one station, but may lay extra as their existing stations are properly surrounded. Owning a station also earns players a small income as other player use the facilities there.

The game continues until one of the tile stacks runs out.

The latest version of the rules and tiles are May 2019. If you have been playing an earlier version, the designer suggests at least looking at the improvements and/or viewing the "how to" video section here on the geek.

Name: Saxon Shore
Description:
Saxon Shore simulates the warfare and politics of Britain after the Roman withdrawal in the fifth century AD. This was a time where the local Britons were beleaguered by waves of settlers from Ireland, Scotland, Scandinavia, and the European mainland. These settlers fought the Britons and one another in an attempt to establish permanent kingdoms. It was a time of economic breakdown, when the Roman coinage was replaced with a system of barter, and also a time of spiritual confusion, with the Christian church coming to dominance in an age of superstition and violence.

In Saxon Shore, two to five players struggle to become the dominant kingdom of the British Isles. A player can win by fulfilling one of several victory conditions:

1. Eliminate all other players.
2. Build four cities.
3. Control eight provinces producing resources.
4. Control any ten provinces.

Name: Imperium Romanum Lite
Description:
The simplified version of West End Games' Imperium Romanum II.

A game for 2-5 players (depending on scenario). The game is a province based simulation of Ancient Rome and her struggles, both internally and with surrounding foes.

http://www.kerpob.com/games/imperium.html

Name: Lukas: oder wie man eine Schleife bindet
Description:
Description from Spielbox:

Dirk Hanneforth invented this teaching game for the very young. Each child gets a colored shoe as well as a matching shoelace. The shoe has holes which have colored edges. Now, the color die comes into play. The first player tries his luck: If the die shows his own color, then he gets to thread his shoelace into one of the next two free holes in his shoe. If it’s a different color, then he has to look carefully: If red was rolled and a free hole is also red, then he gets to thread the lace. If, however, none of the next holes are red, then he gets to give away the color by choosing an opponent who needs the color and can use it to continue threading his lace. As soon as a child has succeeded in completely threading his shoelace, he wins the game. If he can then also tie a knot, he’s laughing. The others can practice via the illustrated instructions.

Ages 4 and up. Artwork: Kerstin Völker

Name: Battle Stations!
Description:
Battle Stations! 1/2400 Naval Rules by Decision Games.

Battle Stations!  Battle Stations! Naval Rules for Fleet Sized Combat for Miniatures

So now that you have the ships how are you going to fight with them?  There are only just a few rule sets out there and all but one are mired in detail and lend themselves to small actions of four ships that is if you want to finish the battle in the same day.  Battle Stations is different in that its emphasis is on medium to large sized battles which can be completed in a day or even in hours.  The designer reckons for each ship involved in the game it adds ten minutes of playing time.

Have it all in one package!  Inside you will find ship stats for all the naval powers which fought in World War II: Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Netherlands, Soviet Union, and United States.  All of the major naval aircraft are here too like the US Hellcat, the Japanese Zero, the Re 2001 (for the Aquila), the British Swordfish, the D520 for the French carrier Bearn.

The ship charts include a comprehensive listing of ship classes ranging from aircraft carriers, battleships, cruisers, destroyers, escorts, commerce raiders (all the German raiders are here), merchant ships, MTBs, submarines and even the experimental battleships like the German H39 class, the improved Gneisenau class with 15” guns, the Graf Zeppelin and Seydlitz German aircraft carriers and the not to be forgotten Italian aircraft carrier Aquila.

But that is not all, you receive extensive listings of the number of ships in each class, when the class became available and when certain ships in the class were sunk.

Damage and speed is kept track of on the game table eliminating extensive paperwork.  Two sided counters tracking speed and damage are provided.  Each turn represents a half hour of time so action is fast, furious, and realistic.  Rules are very comprehensive covering fleet morale, surface combat, mine warfare, torpedo launches, carrier combat, submarine warfare as well as surface combat and damage control (which varies by nation as well as by year). Charts are intuitive, easy to understand and speed play.

Components: 82 page rulebook (17 pages of rules, 31 pages of ship stats, and 10 scenarios), two card stock combat charts, one card stock sheet of templates, 140 counters for marking damage, speed, and submarine depth.

Ten Scenarios: River Plate 1939, Montevideo 1939, Punta Stilo 1940, Spartivento 1940, Sinking of the Hood 1941, Sinking of the Bismarck 1941, Java Sea 1942, Cape Esperance 1942, Guadalcanal 1942, Komandorski Islands 1943.

Name: Sail Ho!
Description:
Sail Ho! Boating Adventure Game MB#4915-6
Ages 6 to 12.  Object: Sail around the Lake. Be the first home. Basically a 112 space track  from start to finish navigated by a 1 to 6 spinner. Within certain sections of the track, only a subset of spinner results lets you advance..."Power Boat Wake 2's and 5's to move" The regions are not always well defined, so I can imagine sibling arguments over whether space 15 is inside or outside the "Brisk Breeze 2's and 4's Double" zone. 
Box contains gameboard, box liner with rules and integrated spinner and four 1" die cut cardboard sailboats on four different colored plastic bases.

Don't expect your kids to learn anything about sailing from this game. The children in the boat on the cover art are not wearing any life vests and I seriously doubt if the little girl is really holding the jib sheet.  Looks to me as if they have it cleated and if the wake is any indication, that boat is going to capsize or broach real soon!

Name: InStructures
Description: A party game where 2 teams race against each other to be the first to build a structure with the blocks provided, but only their “Foremen” get to see the blueprint. Good verbal communication is the key to winning! The game is full of interesting challenges to keep it fresh every time such as: silent foreman, memory challenge, blind foreman and a timed challenge.

Name: Crazy Mixed Up Zoo
Description:
This one will challenge even the sharpest elephant! In Crazy Mixed Up Zoo, animals are switched and turned all around to confuse the players. Can you guess which pair of animals has traded places? Prove you have the memory of an elephant and win the game!

Ages 4+

Name: Pizza Box Football 2006 Expansion
Description:
The Pizza Box Football 2006 Expansion Game Booster updates all teams based on the 2005-2006 season.  The pack also includes the additional expansion plays previewed in Pizza Box Football games as well as the additional gray expansion die.

The booster requires the original Pizza Box Football game.  These cards do not require the original Pizza Box Football Expansion Game.

Expands:

    Pizza Box Football
Families: Game: Pizza Box Sports (On The Line Game Company)

Name: Slap Wacky!
Description:
Slap Wacky is the fast and fun game where you rush to put together the most wacky shape patterns before the cards run out!

Quickly place cards on the table to put together shape patterns as fast as you can. When you complete a pattern, slap it to get the points before another player uses a block card against you. The player who scores the most points wins the game!

Name: Go to Press
Description: Players move from department to department at a newspaper, finding and correcting errors in the newspaper headlines. The first player to create a complete newspaper, return to the boss's office and say, "Go to press!" wins the game. Game cards feature interesting questions.

Name: Vegas Nite Slots
Description:
Object of the game: To win all the cards, bankrupting all other players.

Vegas Nite Slots plays like a One Arm Bandit slot machine.  On your turn, you can play one, two or three cards on any of three piles attempting to get three of the same cards in a row.  If you do, you get a payoff.  If you don't you have lost the cards you just played.

Name: Vegas Nite Roulette
Description:
Object of the game: To be the last player in the game with cards.

Vegas Nite Roulette plays like Roulette.  Players take turns "calling".  First, all players (except the "caller") place their "bets" by placing their card(s) face down on the table.  The "caller" draws a card and calls out a number.  Players with the matching number on their betting cards win.

Name: Blackout
Description: This abstract game includes 6 colored wooden discs and 6 black caps. One player hides the disks and moves things around, the other must note what has changed. This is a simple memory game with some variant options to make it more challenging for adults.

Name: Tip-Top
Description:
Whose turn is it to do the dishes today?
Who will take down the trash?
Who will pay for the next round?
Who is calling the mother-in-law?

Play Tip-Top to decide all of these important questions in your daily life — or compete solely for fun, of course! Each player has a pair of shoes, and starting from a distance of the players' choice, they move toward one another turn by turn, heel to toe, the distance becoming smaller with each step. Crossing your feet is fine, but cheating is prohibited! Whoever fits in the last gap wins. The loser has to...well, what was the challenge again?

Name: Top
Description:
More wooden fun from Steffen Spiele.

Top is a fun dexterity game where players try to trap the stick with a paddle before it drops. It sounds easier than it is, and with varying length sticks the challenge gets greater.

Name: Fuchsen & Mausen
Description: A first - a Steffen-Spiele game made of leather instead of wood! This is a dexterity game where players flick disks of various colored leather to try to reach certain targets.

Name: Dumy Rumy
Description: DUMY RUMY is a great party game and lots of fun the whole family, too. It combines equal parts of skill and luck, courage and cunning... makes addicts out of players in a single session.

Name: Alaska Dyke Life
Description:
A limited edition poster/game, with only 400 printed. A roll and move game featuring localities within Alaska. Art/game produced by Anchorage artist Kenna Bates.

Game takes place on a 23" x 34" poster (suitable for framing). Game pieces and dice not included.

The object of the game is to "collect as many girlfriends as you can!". "Girlfriends" = points, which are traded among players as they move onto different spaces.

Proceeds from the print/game are to support athletes participating in the Montreal Out Games.
